content.user_title: Skill Development for Claude Code Plugins
content.value_statement: Empowers developers to create well-structured, efficient skills for Claude Code plugins using progressive disclosure principles and best practices.
actual_capabilities: Guides developers through the complete skill creation workflow from concept to deployment
Teaches progressive disclosure pattern with three-level loading (metadata, SKILL.md, bundled resources)
Provides concrete examples of skill structure for scripts, references, and assets
Enforces writing style standards (imperative form, third-person descriptions)
Helps optimize skill descriptions with specific trigger phrases for accurate activation
Demonstrates proper organization between SKILL.md (1,500-2,000 words) and references files
limitations: Focused specifically on Claude Code plugin skills, not generic skill creation
Does not provide automated validation tools (only validation checklist)
Requires manual testing to verify skill triggers correctly
No packaging step for plugin skills (distributed as part of plugin)

use_cases.title: Creating a New Plugin Skill
use_cases.description: Developer wants to add a new skill to their Claude Code plugin that helps users work with a specific tool or workflow

use_cases.title: Improving Skill Trigger Accuracy
use_cases.description: Existing skill isn't loading when expected; need to strengthen trigger phrases in description frontmatter

use_cases.title: Refactoring Bloated Skill Documentation
use_cases.description: SKILL.md has grown to 5,000+ words; need to apply progressive disclosure by moving content to references

use_cases.title: Adding Reference Files and Examples
use_cases.description: Skill needs detailed patterns and working code examples without bloating main documentation

prompt_templates.title: Create New Skill
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to create a skill for my plugin that helps users [describe functionality]. Users would say things like "[example query 1]" or "[example query 2]". Can you help me create this skill?
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new skill from scratch

prompt_templates.title: Improve Skill Description
prompt_templates.prompt: My skill isn't triggering when users ask about [topic]. The current description is: [paste description]. Can you help me improve the trigger phrases?

prompt_templates.title: Refactor for Progressive Disclosure
prompt_templates.prompt: My SKILL.md is [X] words long and has detailed content about [topics]. Help me identify what should move to references/ files.

prompt_templates.title: Add Working Examples
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to add examples to my [skill-name] skill. The skill helps with [functionality]. What examples should I include?

output_examples.input: Help me create a skill for database migrations
output_examples.output: Guides through: (1) Understanding concrete use cases ("run migration", "rollback database"), (2) Planning resources (migration script templates in assets/, schema docs in references/), (3) Creating skill structure in plugin, (4) Writing SKILL.md with strong triggers, (5) Validating organization

output_examples.input: My hooks skill description is too vague
output_examples.output: Transforms generic description into: 'This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook", "validate tool use", or mentions hook events (PreToolUse, PostToolUse, Stop).'

best_practices: Keep SKILL.md body between 1,500-2,000 words (max 3,000); move detailed content to references/
Use third-person in frontmatter description: 'This skill should be used when...'
Include specific trigger phrases users would actually say ("create X", "configure Y")
Write skill body in imperative/infinitive form, not second person
Create only directories actually needed (references/, examples/, scripts/)
Reference supporting files clearly in SKILL.md so Claude knows they exist
Study plugin-dev's skills (hook-development, agent-development) as templates
Test skills by triggering with expected user queries
anti_patterns: Writing vague descriptions without specific trigger phrases
Putting all content in SKILL.md without using progressive disclosure
Using second-person writing ("You should...") instead of imperative form
Creating empty directories (references/, scripts/) that aren't needed
Not referencing bundled resources in SKILL.md body
Duplicating information between SKILL.md and references files
Using generic skill-creator's init_skill.py for plugin skills (use manual structure instead)
Forgetting to include version in frontmatter

faq.question: What's the difference between this and the generic skill-creator?
faq.answer: This is specialized for Claude Code plugins. Plugin skills live in plugin's skills/ directory, don't use init_skill.py, don't get packaged as ZIPs (distributed with plugin), and use simpler manual directory creation.

faq.question: How long should SKILL.md be?
faq.answer: Target 1,500-2,000 words for the body. Under 3,000 words maximum. Move detailed content to references/ files to implement progressive disclosure.

faq.question: What makes a good skill description?
faq.answer: Use third-person format with specific trigger phrases users would say: 'This skill should be used when the user asks to "create X", "configure Y", "validate Z"'. Avoid vague descriptions.

faq.question: When should I use references/ vs putting content in SKILL.md?
faq.answer: SKILL.md: core concepts, essential procedures, quick reference. References/: detailed patterns, advanced techniques, comprehensive docs, edge cases. Each reference can be 2,000-5,000+ words.

faq.question: Do I need all three directories (references/, examples/, scripts/)?
faq.answer: No. Only create directories you actually need. Many skills only need references/ and examples/, or just SKILL.md alone for simple cases.

faq.question: How do I test if my skill triggers correctly?
faq.answer: Install plugin locally with cc --plugin-dir /path/to/plugin, then ask questions matching your trigger phrases. Verify skill loads when expected.
